Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation. • Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will
be completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved. •
The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4112 Staff qualifications.
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform the duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Team Leader is inappropriate with Youth L. He gets into her
personal space, visited her at the hospital outside of work hours
and may be "grooming" her.
Investigation These allegations were transferred from MDHHS to DCWL on
6/2/23. On 6/2/23, I attempted to contact Complainant who was
identified as Vista Maria staff. The phone number provided was
not in service and Quality Manager informed me there was no
staff person with that name working at Vista Maria.
I notified Foster Care Worker of this investigation assignment.
She expressed no concerns about the facility.
I notified Quality Manager of the allegations. She told me that
Youth L was in Garden City Hospital’s Emergency Room awaiting
a psychiatric evaluation and Vista Maria placed Team Leader on
administrative leave pending the outcome of the investigation.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I arrived at Garden City Hospital at 1:00pm on 6/2/23. Staff 1 was
sitting with her in her hospital room. I excused Staff 1 and
interviewed Youth L privately. She said she was placed at Vista
Maria a month ago. I asked Youth L if Team Leader behaves
inappropriately with her. Youth L appeared puzzled and asked,
“Who is Team Leader?”
Youth L denied Team Leader or any other male staff at Vista
Maria visited her at the hospital during their off-hours or were ever
inappropriate with her.
I phoned Quality Manager sharing that Youth L does know who
Team Leader is. Later Quality Manager informed me Team
Leader is known to the youths by his nickname and not by the
name indicated in the complaint.
On 6/6/23, I re-interviewed Youth L at the facility with Quality
Manager present. I identified Team Leader by his nickname and
Youth L acknowledged knowing him. She still denied he was
2

ever inappropriate with her. Youth L confirmed that Team Leader
did show up at the hospital for five minutes to “check” on her. She
said he also rode with in the ambulance with her when she was
transported from Vista Maria to the hospital. Youth L said Team
Leader gets along well with her and all the youths and she has no
issues with him.
On 6/7/23, I interviewed Team Leader with Quality Manager
present. He has three years of prior experience as a direct care
worker at another child caring institution, has worked at Vista
Maria for 16 months and was promoted to a Team Leader six
months ago. Team Leader said he did not know Youth L prior to
her admission to Vista Maria. He said he treats all youths the
same and has never been accused of inappropriate behavior.
In contrast to Youth L’s statement, Team Leader said he did sit
with her in her room at Garden City Hospital for two shifts on
5/30/23 and 5/31/23 during work hours. However, on 6/1/23 he
said he worked dayshift at Vista Maria, then stopped at Garden
City Hospital afterward to visit Youth L and three or four other
youths who were also in the emergency department there. Team
Leader said he did not have his employer’s permission to visit the
youths outside of his normal work hours.
Team Leader does not have any disciplinary write-ups in his
employee file.
Analysis The evidence does not support that Team Leader acted
inappropriately or is unable to perform the duties of his assigned
position.
Youth L and Team Leader denied Team Leader is inappropriate,
gets into Youth L's personal space or is sexually "grooming" her.
On his off-hours, Team Leader did visit Youth L and other youths
who were hospitalized. This is addressed in Rule 400.4109
below.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Team Leader wears jogging pants which violates Vista Maria's
staff dress code.
Investigation Team Leader admitted he sometimes wears jogging pants to
work. I reviewed Vista Maria’s staff dress code policy. The policy
does not prohibit direct care staff or supervisors from wearing
jogging pants.
Relative to Team Leader visiting Youth L at the hospital during his
off-hours, I reviewed the agency’s staff and client interaction
policy. The policy indicates staff are not to socialize with current
or former clients except during Vista Maria-sponsored activities.
Team Leader admitted he went to Garden City Hospital after work
to visit Youth L and three or four other youths who were
hospitalized there. Vista Maria was not aware he visited the
youths, and he did not have his employer’s preapproval to visit
them outside of his normal work hours.
Analysis Team Leader did not follow the agency’s staff and client
interaction policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
